pullRequest.body:
The n-th Harmonic number is not an integer for n > 1. This proof uses 2-adic valuations. 
 
---

This proof is of Theorem 1 in Keith Conrad's [blurb](https://kconrad.math.uconn.edu/blurbs/gradnumthy/padicharmonicsum.pdf). This proof is credited to K√ºrsch√°k (1918). From this it follows that the 2-adic valuation of `H_n` tends to infinity as `n` does. We quickly run into open problems when similar questions are asked for odd primes `p`.  

[![Open in Gitpod](https://gitpod.io/button/open-in-gitpod.svg)](https://gitpod.io/from-referrer/)

nodes.body: @Ruben-VandeVelde thank you for your comments, I've incorporated most of them and the build passes. @alexjbest suggested that we could move this material out of Counterexamples and into mathlib proper. I could do that as a follow up PR if that works.
i think i've addressed most of the comments - just waiting now for the build to turn green, thanks everyone!

It seems like induction can be used to simplify the main proof:
```
open BigOperators

/-- The nth-harmonic number defined as a finset sum of consecutive reciprocals. -/
def harmonic : ‚Ñï ‚Üí ‚Ñö := fun n => ‚àë i in Finset.range n, (‚Üë(i + 1))‚Åª¬π

@[simp]
lemma harmonic_zero : harmonic 0 = 0 :=
  rfl

@[simp]
lemma harmonic_succ (n : ‚Ñï) : harmonic (n + 1) = harmonic n + (‚Üë(n + 1))‚Åª¬π := by
  apply Finset.sum_range_succ

lemma harmonic_pos {n : ‚Ñï} (Hn : n ‚â† 0) : 0 < harmonic n :=
  Finset.sum_pos (fun n _ => inv_pos.mpr (Nat.cast_pos.mpr n.succ_pos))
    (Finset.nonempty_range_iff.mpr Hn)

lemma key1 {n : ‚Ñï} (hn : n ‚â† 0) : Nat.log 2 n ‚â† padicValNat 2 (n + 1) := by
  rw [Ne, Nat.log_eq_iff (by simp [hn])]
  rintro ‚ü®h1, h2‚ü©
  rw [‚Üê Nat.lt_add_one_iff, ‚Üê mul_one (2 ^ _)] at h1
  rw [‚Üê Nat.add_one_le_iff, pow_succ'] at h2
  refine' Nat.not_dvd_of_between_consec_multiples h1 (lt_of_le_of_ne' h2 _) pow_padicValNat_dvd
  exact pow_succ_padicValNat_not_dvd n.succ_ne_zero ‚àò dvd_of_eq

lemma key2 (n : ‚Ñï) : max (Nat.log 2 n) (padicValNat 2 (n + 1)) = Nat.log 2 (n + 1) := by
  apply le_antisymm (max_le (Nat.le_log_of_pow_le one_lt_two (Nat.pow_log_le_add_one 2 n))
    (Nat.le_log_of_pow_le one_lt_two (Nat.le_of_dvd n.succ_pos pow_padicValNat_dvd)))
  rw [le_max_iff, or_iff_not_imp_left, not_le]
  intro h
  replace h := le_antisymm (Nat.add_one_le_iff.mpr (Nat.lt_pow_of_log_lt one_lt_two h))
    (Nat.pow_log_le_self 2 n.succ_ne_zero)
  rw [h, padicValNat.prime_pow, ‚Üê h]

/-- The 2-adic valuation of the n-th harmonic number is the negative of the logarithm
    of n. -/
theorem harmonic_two_adicValRat {n : ‚Ñï} : padicValRat 2 (harmonic n) = -Nat.log 2 n := by
  induction' n with n ih
  ¬∑ simp
  ¬∑ rcases eq_or_ne n 0 with rfl | hn
    ¬∑ simp
    rw [harmonic_succ]
    have key : padicValRat 2 (harmonic n) ‚â† padicValRat 2 (‚Üë(n + 1))‚Åª¬π
    ¬∑ rw [ih, padicValRat.inv, padicValRat.of_nat, Ne, neg_inj, Nat.cast_inj]
      exact key1 hn
    rw [padicValRat.min_eq_padicValRat_add (harmonic_succ n ‚ñ∏ (harmonic_pos n.succ_ne_zero).ne')
        (harmonic_pos hn).ne' (inv_ne_zero (Nat.cast_ne_zero.mpr n.succ_ne_zero)) key, ih,
        padicValRat.inv, padicValRat.of_nat, min_neg_neg, neg_inj, ‚Üê Nat.cast_max, Nat.cast_inj]
    exact key2 n

/-- The n-th harmonic number is not an integer for n ‚â• 2. -/
theorem harmonic_not_int {n : ‚Ñï} (h : 1 < n) : ¬¨(harmonic n).isInt := by
  apply padicNorm.not_int_of_not_padic_int 2
  rw [padicNorm.eq_zpow_of_nonzero (harmonic_pos (ne_zero_of_lt h)).ne',
      harmonic_two_adicValRat, neg_neg, zpow_coe_nat]
  exact one_lt_pow one_lt_two (Nat.log_pos one_lt_two h).ne'
```

```suggestion
/-- If the p-adic valuation of a finite set of positive rationals is greater than a given rational
number, then the p-adic valuation of their sum is also greater than the same rational number. -/
```

```suggestion
    padicValRat p (q + r) = padicValRat p q := by
  rw [min_eq_padicValRat_add hqr hq hr (ne_of_lt hval),min_eq_left (le_of_lt hval)]
```

Try and follow this indentation style throughout the file (look at files in mathlib for more examples) but we do 4 spaces for the statement and 2 for the proof now (and tend to put by on the previous line)

This feels like it should be a quick consequence of two simpler lemmas, one saying `(Finset.range n).Nontrivial` and one saying that `s.Nontrivial ‚Üí (s \ {c}).Nonempty`. And can you move it to an earlier file?

I tried this for a while but gave up. I tried to put this in `Finset.Basic` but the lemmas there don't know `linarith` apparently. This is what I could come up with: 
```lean
lemma finset_range_sdiff_singleton_nonempty {c n : ‚Ñï} (hn : 2 ‚â§ n) :
    Finset.Nonempty (Finset.range n \ {c}) := by
  rw [Finset.sdiff_nonempty, Finset.subset_singleton_iff, Finset.range_eq_empty_iff, not_or]
  refine' ‚ü®ne_of_gt <| lt_of_lt_of_le zero_lt_two hn, fun Hnot => _‚ü©
  have : n = 1 := by rw [‚Üê Finset.card_range n, ‚Üê Finset.card_singleton c, Hnot]
  simp only [this] at hn
```
Feel free to golf this and commit if you can

I mean that you should write two lemmas, one saying `(Finset.range n).Nontrivial` and one saying that `s.Nontrivial ‚Üí (s \ {c}).Nonempty`. You might need to merge master to get access to `Finset.Nontrivial`.

This is already done in 38884190410085716619b1cf03d126b033546b90. See `padicValRat.self_pow_div`. I use this lemma twice in two proofs below so I factored it out as a local lemma. I can't seem to use `self_pow_div` directly because of an implicit coercion in the proof below.

This feels simpler. That being said, I feel like `Rat.isInt` isn't quite the right tool for the job, since it is `Bool` and not `Prop`.
```suggestion
lemma _root_.Rat.isInt.eq_num {q : ‚Ñö} (h : q.isInt) : q = q.num := by
  rw [Rat.isInt, Nat.beq_eq_true_eq] at h
  exact (Rat.coe_int_num_of_den_eq_one h).symm

/-- If a rational is not a p-adic integer, it is not an integer. -/
theorem not_int_of_not_padic_int (p : ‚Ñï) {a : ‚Ñö} [hp : Fact (Nat.Prime p)]
    (H : 1 < padicNorm p a) : ¬¨ a.isInt := by
  contrapose! H
  rw [Rat.isInt.eq_num H]
  apply padicNorm.of_int
```

```suggestion
lemma padicValRat_def (p : ‚Ñï) (q : ‚Ñö) :
    padicValRat p q = padicValInt p q.num - padicValNat p q.den :=
  rfl
```

```suggestion
  have h1 := min_le_padicValRat_add (p := p) hqr
  have h2 := min_le_padicValRat_add (p := p) (ne_of_eq_of_ne (add_neg_cancel_right q r) hq)
  have h3 := min_le_padicValRat_add (p := p) (ne_of_eq_of_ne (add_neg_cancel_right r q) hr)
  rw [add_neg_cancel_right, padicValRat.neg] at h2 h3
  rw [add_comm] at h3
  refine' le_antisymm (le_min _ _) h1
  ¬∑ contrapose! h2
    rw [min_eq_right h2.le] at h3
    exact lt_min h2 (lt_of_le_of_ne h3 hval)
  ¬∑ contrapose! h3
    rw [min_eq_right h3.le] at h2
    exact lt_min h3 (lt_of_le_of_ne h2 hval.symm)
```
Perhaps this lemma should be called something like `add_eq_min`?
Maybe this lemma should be called `lt_add_of_lt`?

```suggestion
lemma self_pow_div (r : ‚Ñï) : padicValRat p ((p : ‚Ñö) ^ r)‚Åª¬π = -r := by
  rw [padicValRat.inv, neg_inj, padicValRat.pow (Nat.cast_ne_zero.mpr hp.elim.ne_zero),
      padicValRat.self hp.elim.one_lt, mul_one]
```

```suggestion
  ¬∑ rw [padicValNat.zero, Nat.log_zero_right]
  ¬∑ refine' Nat.le_log_of_pow_le hp.elim.one_lt _
    exact le_of_dvd (Nat.pos_of_ne_zero h) pow_padicValNat_dvd
```

```suggestion
  rw [padicNorm.eq_zpow_of_nonzero (harmonic_pos (by linarith)).ne']
```

I think usually `n‚Åª¬π` is preferred over `1 / n` (analogous to how `-n` is the preferred over `0 - n`).
```suggestion
def harmonic : ‚Ñï ‚Üí ‚Ñö := fun n => ‚àë i in Finset.range n, (‚Üë(i + 1))‚Åª¬π
```
But we also have: https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Analysis/PSeries.html#Real.tendsto_sum_range_one_div_nat_succ_atTop which does `1/(i+1)`.

This allows for dot notation.
```suggestion
theorem Nontrivial.sdiff_singleton_nonempty {c : Œ±} {s : Finset Œ±} (hS : s.Nontrivial) :
```

(And switching to `n‚Åª¬π` should in theory make some proofs a bit tidier)
```suggestion
  Finset.sum_pos (fun _ _ => inv_pos.mpr (by norm_cast; linarith))
```
It also breaks other proofs down below which I'm quite weary of fixing... If this is a matter of taste, I'd prefer to leave it as is. Other places in mathlib do use `1/x` as I've linked to above.
I opened a discussion on Zulip: https://leanprover.zulipchat.com/#narrow/stream/144837-PR-reviews/topic/.237319.20harmonic.20number.20not.20an.20integer

```suggestion
    padicValRat 2 (harmonic n) = -Nat.log 2 n := by
  rw [harmonic_singleton (two_pow_log_sub_one_mem_range Hn)]
```

```suggestion
theorem harmonic_not_int {n : ‚Ñï} (h : 2 ‚â§ n) : ¬¨ (harmonic n).isInt := by
  apply padicNorm.not_int_of_not_padic_int 2
  rw [padicNorm.eq_zpow_of_nonzero (harmonic_pos (ne_zero_of_lt h)).ne',
      padicValRat_two_harmonic h, neg_neg, zpow_coe_nat]
  exact one_lt_pow one_lt_two (Nat.log_pos one_lt_two h).ne'
```

```suggestion
lemma Nat.log_ne_padicValNat_succ {n : ‚Ñï} (hn : n ‚â† 0) : log 2 n ‚â† padicValNat 2 (n + 1) := by
  rw [Ne, log_eq_iff (by simp [hn])]
  rintro ‚ü®h1, h2‚ü©
  rw [‚Üê lt_add_one_iff, ‚Üê mul_one (2 ^ _)] at h1
  rw [‚Üê add_one_le_iff, pow_succ] at h2
  refine' not_dvd_of_between_consec_multiples h1 (lt_of_le_of_ne' h2 _) pow_padicValNat_dvd
  exact pow_succ_padicValNat_not_dvd n.succ_ne_zero ‚àò dvd_of_eq

lemma Nat.max_log_padicValNat_succ_eq_log_succ (n : ‚Ñï) :
    max (log 2 n) (padicValNat 2 (n + 1)) = log 2 (n + 1) := by
  apply le_antisymm (max_le (le_log_of_pow_le one_lt_two (pow_log_le_add_one 2 n))
    (le_log_of_pow_le one_lt_two (le_of_dvd n.succ_pos pow_padicValNat_dvd)))
  rw [le_max_iff, or_iff_not_imp_left, not_le]
  intro h
  replace h := le_antisymm (add_one_le_iff.mpr (lt_pow_of_log_lt one_lt_two h))
    (pow_log_le_self 2 n.succ_ne_zero)
  rw [h, padicValNat.prime_pow, ‚Üê h]

/-- The 2-adic valuation of the n-th harmonic number is the negative of the logarithm
    of n. -/
theorem padicValRat_two_harmonic {n : ‚Ñï} : padicValRat 2 (harmonic n) = -Nat.log 2 n := by
  induction' n with n ih
  ¬∑ simp
  ¬∑ rcases eq_or_ne n 0 with rfl | hn
    ¬∑ simp
    rw [harmonic_succ]
    have key : padicValRat 2 (harmonic n) ‚â† padicValRat 2 (‚Üë(n + 1))‚Åª¬π
    ¬∑ rw [ih, padicValRat.inv, padicValRat.of_nat, Ne, neg_inj, Nat.cast_inj]
      exact Nat.log_ne_padicValNat_succ hn
    rw [padicValRat.add_eq_min (harmonic_succ n ‚ñ∏ (harmonic_pos n.succ_ne_zero).ne')
        (harmonic_pos hn).ne' (inv_ne_zero (Nat.cast_ne_zero.mpr n.succ_ne_zero)) key, ih,
        padicValRat.inv, padicValRat.of_nat, min_neg_neg, neg_inj, ‚Üê Nat.cast_max, Nat.cast_inj]
    exact Nat.max_log_padicValNat_succ_eq_log_succ n
```

You would also need these simp-lemmas:
```
@[simp]
lemma harmonic_zero : harmonic 0 = 0 :=
  rfl

@[simp]
lemma harmonic_succ (n : ‚Ñï) : harmonic (n + 1) = harmonic n + (‚Üë(n + 1))‚Åª¬π := by
  apply Finset.sum_range_succ
```
Done! Thanks


```suggestion
lemma padicValNat_le_nat_log (n : ‚Ñï) : padicValNat p n ‚â§ Nat.log p n := by
  rcases n with _ | n
  ¬∑ simp
  rcases p with _ | _ | p
  ¬∑ simp
  ¬∑ simp
  exact Nat.le_log_of_pow_le p.one_lt_succ_succ (le_of_dvd n.succ_pos pow_padicValNat_dvd)
```
These last two lemmas are no longer used.
Yeah but they'd be good to have around.
The second one seems potentially useful, but this first lemma just gives a weaker upper bound than the preceding lemma, I think?
I use the first lemma in the proof of the second, so might as well factor it out into its own lemma?
Sorry, I meant that `le_nat_log_of_le` doesn't improve on the upper bound in `padicValNat_le_nat_log`, so I'm not sure whether it makes sense to keep `le_nat_log_of_le`.
Ah okay, I agree. I just removed it.

pullRequest.title: [Merged by Bors] - feat: the n-th harmonic number is not an integer for n > 1.

nodes.body: Please don't be intimidated by the comments below, they're simple stylistic suggestions

@Ruben-VandeVelde thank you for your comments, I've incorporated most of them and the build passes. @alexjbest suggested that we could move this material out of Counterexamples and into mathlib proper. I could do that as a follow up PR if that works.
i think i've addressed most of the comments - just waiting now for the build to turn green, thanks everyone!

It seems like induction can be used to simplify the main proof:
```
open BigOperators

/-- The nth-harmonic number defined as a finset sum of consecutive reciprocals. -/
def harmonic : ‚Ñï ‚Üí ‚Ñö := fun n => ‚àë i in Finset.range n, (‚Üë(i + 1))‚Åª¬π

@[simp]
lemma harmonic_zero : harmonic 0 = 0 :=
  rfl

@[simp]
lemma harmonic_succ (n : ‚Ñï) : harmonic (n + 1) = harmonic n + (‚Üë(n + 1))‚Åª¬π := by
  apply Finset.sum_range_succ

lemma harmonic_pos {n : ‚Ñï} (Hn : n ‚â† 0) : 0 < harmonic n :=
  Finset.sum_pos (fun n _ => inv_pos.mpr (Nat.cast_pos.mpr n.succ_pos))
    (Finset.nonempty_range_iff.mpr Hn)

lemma key1 {n : ‚Ñï} (hn : n ‚â† 0) : Nat.log 2 n ‚â† padicValNat 2 (n + 1) := by
  rw [Ne, Nat.log_eq_iff (by simp [hn])]
  rintro ‚ü®h1, h2‚ü©
  rw [‚Üê Nat.lt_add_one_iff, ‚Üê mul_one (2 ^ _)] at h1
  rw [‚Üê Nat.add_one_le_iff, pow_succ'] at h2
  refine' Nat.not_dvd_of_between_consec_multiples h1 (lt_of_le_of_ne' h2 _) pow_padicValNat_dvd
  exact pow_succ_padicValNat_not_dvd n.succ_ne_zero ‚àò dvd_of_eq

lemma key2 (n : ‚Ñï) : max (Nat.log 2 n) (padicValNat 2 (n + 1)) = Nat.log 2 (n + 1) := by
  apply le_antisymm (max_le (Nat.le_log_of_pow_le one_lt_two (Nat.pow_log_le_add_one 2 n))
    (Nat.le_log_of_pow_le one_lt_two (Nat.le_of_dvd n.succ_pos pow_padicValNat_dvd)))
  rw [le_max_iff, or_iff_not_imp_left, not_le]
  intro h
  replace h := le_antisymm (Nat.add_one_le_iff.mpr (Nat.lt_pow_of_log_lt one_lt_two h))
    (Nat.pow_log_le_self 2 n.succ_ne_zero)
  rw [h, padicValNat.prime_pow, ‚Üê h]

/-- The 2-adic valuation of the n-th harmonic number is the negative of the logarithm
    of n. -/
theorem harmonic_two_adicValRat {n : ‚Ñï} : padicValRat 2 (harmonic n) = -Nat.log 2 n := by
  induction' n with n ih
  ¬∑ simp
  ¬∑ rcases eq_or_ne n 0 with rfl | hn
    ¬∑ simp
    rw [harmonic_succ]
    have key : padicValRat 2 (harmonic n) ‚â† padicValRat 2 (‚Üë(n + 1))‚Åª¬π
    ¬∑ rw [ih, padicValRat.inv, padicValRat.of_nat, Ne, neg_inj, Nat.cast_inj]
      exact key1 hn
    rw [padicValRat.min_eq_padicValRat_add (harmonic_succ n ‚ñ∏ (harmonic_pos n.succ_ne_zero).ne')
        (harmonic_pos hn).ne' (inv_ne_zero (Nat.cast_ne_zero.mpr n.succ_ne_zero)) key, ih,
        padicValRat.inv, padicValRat.of_nat, min_neg_neg, neg_inj, ‚Üê Nat.cast_max, Nat.cast_inj]
    exact key2 n

/-- The n-th harmonic number is not an integer for n ‚â• 2. -/
theorem harmonic_not_int {n : ‚Ñï} (h : 1 < n) : ¬¨(harmonic n).isInt := by
  apply padicNorm.not_int_of_not_padic_int 2
  rw [padicNorm.eq_zpow_of_nonzero (harmonic_pos (ne_zero_of_lt h)).ne',
      harmonic_two_adicValRat, neg_neg, zpow_coe_nat]
  exact one_lt_pow one_lt_two (Nat.log_pos one_lt_two h).ne'
```
@tb65536 Can we just merge this and you can make your proof as a PR later? Or, better yet: feel free to push your changes onto this branch.
I do suggest you consider proving `padicValRat_two_harmonic` by induction. It's shorter and avoids the hypothesis `2 ‚â§ n`.
Looking very good. Maybe someone else can take one last look over?
lgtm once those last two comments are taken care of
